title: To those who believe wearing a mask is taking away your freedom, why?

body:
I don't know anything about the national conversation on this topic because I don't watch the news, I'm very detached from social media trends because other than ruqqus I don't have social media, and so on. 

That said, I don't want to wear a mask because there is nothing about this flu that concerns me. If the argument is 'by wearing a mask you help others', my response is, why am I being forced to care about others? If you want to try to shame me for not being considerate enough, I don't really care. I don't think, 'All Lives Matter'. In fact, outside of my immediate family there are nearly no lives that matter to me. So please, tell me, why am I required to wear a mask?

post.title: To those who believe wearing a mask is taking away your freedom, why?

body:
I used to believe in masks, but now they've started banning "valve" masks which include P100s, N95s that are publicly available, and actual gas masks. So basically all the masks that could actually protect you from a virus.

Instead i'm forced to wear a cheap cloth masks where I can feel the air flowing in and out the sides, on the assumption this will "slow the spread". They straight up admit these masks don't protect you at all.

If i'm wearing a mask the priority should be protecting myself first and protecting others second. People who want to protect themselves can get their own mask. Why not just let people put cloth filters over the valves? Then they protect others just as much as these useless cloth masks. But no, cities are more concerned with uniformity and control than they are with actually protecting anyone, or letting you protect yourself.

If they really wanted to stop this virus the government would give out N95s to everybody, but they don't.

body: I wear a mask but Americans are perpetually afraid of giving the government an inch out of fear they'll take a mile. Some of us choose weird ways of standing our ground. Not wearing a mask sounds ridiculous to me but my angst about the government wanting backdoors in encrypted devices probably sounds stupid to someone else. I dunno, America was built on individual freedoms, and sometimes that expresses itself in strange ways.

body: I'm not planning shit. I've read stories of cities issuing tickets and jail time for now mask. I don't agree with that at all. I think it should be encouraged but not mandatory unless in a privately owned business. I think that my POV is a bit different as I'm a social chameleon. I kind of go along and toe the line until it becomes unsavory for me then I do whatever the fuck I want. I feel this method keeps others out of my business better as they think I'm just a regular Joe.

post.title: To those who believe wearing a mask is taking away your freedom, why?

body:
Generally speaking I do see a few underlying reasons why people would reject this mask idea:

- trust in government and other officials like medical professionals is at an all time low
- societal trust is at rock bottom because we don't actually live in a society but rather an economic zone in which we all operate autonomously from each other and without social cohesion or bonds we are not compelled to help strangers
- social pressure in many areas have ramped up significantly so resistance to what would otherwise be insignificant requests has also increased

Basically, people are fed up with being pushed around so they're acting irrationally. It's not limited to masks, for example, we just had several months of riots over the death of a drugged out violent criminal. 

Social unrest is at an all time high. Stay frosty.

body: To me, it's not about the masks themselves, it's about the kind of information the people get nowadays. People are in mass hysteria about about a disease similar to the flu because the media made it sound scary. The Nigerian doctor along with some other doctors working for the US said that hydroxychloroquine helps with COVID due to it being a respiratory disease, and what happened next? Twitter & YouTube proceed to censor it. If this is the kind of biased information people are getting now, think of what the future could hold.

body: Because wearing shoes inside of stores is a company policy, not the law. If a store wants to kick people out for not wearing masks, that's perfectly fine, and you can go to another store that won't. But when the government uses it as an excuse to take over and enforce things globally, that's what we don't like.

Yeah that's the same type I wear, I also put the material from the cheap cloth masks over the valves, so nobody should be able to complain.

Somebody on Twitter made an announcement about it:
https://twitter.com/i/events/1285526322194706438

Disney banned them
https://www.deseret.com/entertainment/2020/7/29/21345001/coronavirus-disney-world-face-mask-ban

Then basically all businesses where I live that currently require masks are now saying no valves are allowed.

https://www.forbes.com/sites/suzannerowankelleher/2020/05/26/why-some-cities-and-counties-are-banning-face-masks-with-valves/

body:
I'm fine with wearing a mask. I do wear a mask in public even though no law is compelling me to do so because I think it is a good idea. 

I'm fine with business requiring people to wear a mask. I think this is also good.

I am, however, opposed to the government forcing me to wear a mask. I think it is an overreach of their authority.
body_html:
I'm fine with wearing a mask. I do wear a mask in public even though no law is compelling me to do so because I think it is a good idea.

I'm fine with business requiring people to wear a mask. I think this is also good.

I am, however, opposed to the government forcing me to wear a mask. I think it is an overreach of their authority.

body:
Because it's about giving the government more power, it might be masks today, but what will be the next thing that the government will force us to wear or inject into our body for "our protection".

To top it all off most of the masks people are wearing, are not really effective at stopping the virus because they can't filter well enough.  And then I'd say a good 40% of people I see wearing a mask, are not wearing one correctly, they'll either have it under their nose, around their chin (basically not wearing it at all) or it wont be tight on their face.  I'll also see people wear gloves, but then touch their mask or their face.  Like what's the point of wearing it if you're not going to do it properly, you're just wearing it to conform.

I live with someone who is a high risk person, I do my part by not going out unless I need to, and washing my hands.

body:
I want to tangent on living in a society vs economic zone as your comment gave me a thought.

I wonder if we as a race have reached a point where we are less motivated to care for others because there are so many of us?
For example, 1,000 years ago, people in a community needed to work together and support each other to prevent disaster or destruction.  And communities working together are a society (I think).

But now we have such a successful environment that the idea a community or society being wiped out, we don't _need_ to support each other - so we are doing it less.

thoughts?

parent.body:
Generally speaking I do see a few underlying reasons why people would reject this mask idea:

- trust in government and other officials like medical professionals is at an all time low
- societal trust is at rock bottom because we don't actually live in a society but rather an economic zone in which we all operate autonomously from each other and without social cohesion or bonds we are not compelled to help strangers
- social pressure in many areas have ramped up significantly so resistance to what would otherwise be insignificant requests has also increased

Basically, people are fed up with being pushed around so they're acting irrationally. It's not limited to masks, for example, we just had several months of riots over the death of a drugged out violent criminal. 

Social unrest is at an all time high. Stay frosty.

body: Your general theme is correct. Evolution has ingrained within us the resistance to suffering and hardship, which we've endured for millennia by bonding with members of our tribe/society/nation. With the external suffering and hardship mostly eliminated, we not only cease to care about our fellow man due to the dissolution of our society, but we are also intentionally seeking hardships (sjw culture) to validate our existence. We need to live for a cause as humans, and that has gone missing mostly due to our 'age of plenty'. A cool book to read about this is, 'The Way of Men'. It's a short ~150 pager and talks exactly about this topic.

post.title: To those who believe wearing a mask is taking away your freedom, why?

body:
It's not wearing a mask it's forcing me to wear a mask.
In a store or a house it's a private property, they can force me to remove or put on my shoes on, or to wear a mask. It's their policy.
Now in my private life I own my body and I can take the risk that I want to. I can also evaluate the risk for myself. I have been at home for the past 6 months, not getting in contact with anyone. The risk of transmission when I am out in a park is almost non existent. I respect people space and go 2meters away from them when I pass by someone. So why add a mask that will absolutely not reduce the risk in my case.
This will be all solved by the way if there was no common goods. If all area were privatised people could choose to go to parks where masks are mandatory or those were masks are not. This will give us a choice.

author.bio: I'm actually a human not a bunch of kittens that have been experimented on and taught human language
author.bio_html: I'm actually a human not a bunch of kittens that have been experimented on and taught human language

body:
There are a number of commonly made arguments I would support.  Mask effectiveness is highly questionable, for one.  For another, the situation is simply not serious enough for governments to be imposing such crazy mandates on the populace.  It ignores so many potential psychological repercussions on developing children, creating increases in the feeling of isolation, making communication harder (especially for, say, deaf people who lip read).  I also believe any government restriction such as this needs an explicit condition for it to end and can never be allowed to be indefinite.  Anyone proposing a mask requirement without proposing a clear end date to the requirement is just taking power that they never plan to relinquish, just like the TSA after 9/11.  This should terrify any thinking person.  There's also the impact on people with claustrophobia like my mother, or mild asthma like myself.  People unironically make the claim that it's "not a big deal", which to me is just a factually ignorant claim.

All of those are common arguments that people could argue one way or the other.  I think there's a completely rock solid argument that's totally independent though, which is that mask mandates among the general population will not save a single life even if they happened to be effective in slowing the spread.  This is because herd immunity (through infection) is the only realistic end to the virus.

There are 3 ways in which the 'rona pandemic can end:
1) Global eradication, (completely not going to happen given how infectious the virus is)
2) Herd immunity through sufficient vaccination (not going to happen anytime soon; the quickest we've ever created a vaccine is in 4 years, and we've never created a vaccine for a coronavirus.  I'd be shocked if the end of year predictions were true, and even that seems way too slow to beat (3) in the timetable especially when you consider the time needed after getting a vaccine to produce it and disseminate it, and this doesn't even begin to consider whether the vaccine might be less safe than usual due to rushing through the testing process)
3) Herd immunity through infection.  This is why the virus has largely died out in much of Europe.  No, it wasn't "because of lockdown", just look at Sweden.  The same thing happens; you reach enough infected, and the virus stops finding enough uninfected new hosts.  People try to claim that low serology results indicate this hasn't happened, but it's pretty impossible to get around the evidence that cases just start going away at a certain point regardless of the nation's policy decisions.

What this means is that you have to have roughly the same fixed percent of your population infected to beat this.  Because the hospital overwhelmed thing turned out to be a complete non-issue (just look at the extra hospitals that were never used) there's no reason to flatten the curve, so you might as well just get it over with.  Slowing the spread, ergo, does not save lives ultimately, therefore there is no upside to masks, only downsides.  Even the slightest inconvenience therefore should be completely unacceptable to stopping the spread, because it is downside with no upside.

That is the broad point, but now I'm going to add a little nuance and explain the niche circumstance where what I just said could be wrong.  We know that the 'rona mainly kills the elderly, and that it's less deadly than the flu for young people.  Therefore while the number of total cases for herd immunity may be roughly fixed, the number of deaths and the human suffering is actually slightly malleable.  If we infect young people instead of old people, we reduce the death toll.  Thus if you want to impose measures on your most vulnerable for a short time while NOT doing so on people who are relatively young so that they get the disease while the more at risk don't, then you might save lives if your measures are effective.  In my mind, this could justify some amount of intervention for nursing homes, and maybe the truly severely immuno-compromised.  I think we need to be careful though; people in nursing homes typically have very little time left on this earth, and they may prefer seeing their families in person and unmasked to being alone but safe.  Ultimately this risk-reward tradeoff should be made at the nursing home and individual level in my mind and should entirely be outside the realm of government, or maybe at most the government could spend money on making sure at risk people have assistance if they want it.  I'm a more libertarian leaning chap myself and don't care much for big government spending, but I get that opinions differ here and I'd massively prefer a targeted approach towards people who really need help to the mad lockdown and government spending orgy that's happened here in the USA.

I think the whole thing is utterly baffling.  Up until 2020, nobody considered lockdowns as a plausible strategy against disease.  At the start, people just wanted to flatten the curve because they all recognized you couldn't eradicate it, and yet for some reason people now seem to think we can either eradicate it or wait until a vaccine magically appears.  People somehow have convinced themselves this vaccine will be 100% effective, will be here soon, and is guaranteed to be possible despite no coronavirus vaccine ever having been successfully created.  They have no answer for "what happens if we can't make a vaccine?".  Worse, people now claim we always intended to lock down forever.  But that's not the only revisionism we've experienced.

The masks seem to have become popular after the BLM protests.  My opinion is that initially the media railed against anyone protesting lockdown; I've seen things as extreme as wishing death upon people for having these views differing from the media orthodoxy on the virus.  However, it was politically forbidden to be too harsh on the BLM protests.  Regardless of how you feel about that movement, you can't deny that the media treated the two very differently.  Normally I would hope nearly everyone supports the right to protest regardless of whether you agree in the cause, but in this case one was considered okay, even virtuous, while the other abhorrent.  The justification that I saw seemed to be that the BLM protesters were more likely to wear masks, and after that the mask thing caught steam.  To me, it feels like a psychological trick to make people feel like they're "doing something".  It's virtue signalling at its finest.  People get so emotional about their obsessive desire to mask people; it's like they want to feel in control, and they want their "team" to be identifiable by a uniform.  What's more is that people now act like masks always made sense, and all the things that were initially said about them not being shown to work are now irrelevant.  Again, revisionism; we were always at war with Eastasia, covid-1984, etc.

This turned into a bit of a rant, but the tl;dr and crux of my argument is that I don't recognize a point in slowing the spread.  I think we've lost the common sense understanding that the curve has to happen and herd immunity has to achieved and have instead dived into totalitarian madness.  All of the anti-'rona measures seem to be aimed at slowing the spread, and they just don't make sense to me unless you really buy into the magic vaccine will save us thing.  And then on top of that you'd have to prove to me that the masks actually do enough to be effective at stopping the spread, and then you'd have to prove to me that the virus is deadly enough that we should give up our liberties for it.
body_html:
There are a number of commonly made arguments I would support. Mask effectiveness is highly questionable, for one. For another, the situation is simply not serious enough for governments to be imposing such crazy mandates on the populace. It ignores so many potential psychological repercussions on developing children, creating increases in the feeling of isolation, making communication harder (especially for, say, deaf people who lip read). I also believe any government restriction such as this needs an explicit condition for it to end and can never be allowed to be indefinite. Anyone proposing a mask requirement without proposing a clear end date to the requirement is just taking power that they never plan to relinquish, just like the TSA after 9/11. This should terrify any thinking person. There's also the impact on people with claustrophobia like my mother, or mild asthma like myself. People unironically make the claim that it's "not a big deal", which to me is just a factually ignorant claim.

All of those are common arguments that people could argue one way or the other. I think there's a completely rock solid argument that's totally independent though, which is that mask mandates among the general population will not save a single life even if they happened to be effective in slowing the spread. This is because herd immunity (through infection) is the only realistic end to the virus.

There are 3 ways in which the 'rona pandemic can end:

  1. Global eradication, (completely not going to happen given how infectious the virus is)
  2. Herd immunity through sufficient vaccination (not going to happen anytime soon; the quickest we've ever created a vaccine is in 4 years, and we've never created a vaccine for a coronavirus. I'd be shocked if the end of year predictions were true, and even that seems way too slow to beat (3) in the timetable especially when you consider the time needed after getting a vaccine to produce it and disseminate it, and this doesn't even begin to consider whether the vaccine might be less safe than usual due to rushing through the testing process)
  3. Herd immunity through infection. This is why the virus has largely died out in much of Europe. No, it wasn't "because of lockdown", just look at Sweden. The same thing happens; you reach enough infected, and the virus stops finding enough uninfected new hosts. People try to claim that low serology results indicate this hasn't happened, but it's pretty impossible to get around the evidence that cases just start going away at a certain point regardless of the nation's policy decisions.

What this means is that you have to have roughly the same fixed percent of your population infected to beat this. Because the hospital overwhelmed thing turned out to be a complete non-issue (just look at the extra hospitals that were never used) there's no reason to flatten the curve, so you might as well just get it over with. Slowing the spread, ergo, does not save lives ultimately, therefore there is no upside to masks, only downsides. Even the slightest inconvenience therefore should be completely unacceptable to stopping the spread, because it is downside with no upside.

That is the broad point, but now I'm going to add a little nuance and explain the niche circumstance where what I just said could be wrong. We know that the 'rona mainly kills the elderly, and that it's less deadly than the flu for young people. Therefore while the number of total cases for herd immunity may be roughly fixed, the number of deaths and the human suffering is actually slightly malleable. If we infect young people instead of old people, we reduce the death toll. Thus if you want to impose measures on your most vulnerable for a short time while NOT doing so on people who are relatively young so that they get the disease while the more at risk don't, then you might save lives if your measures are effective. In my mind, this could justify some amount of intervention for nursing homes, and maybe the truly severely immuno-compromised. I think we need to be careful though; people in nursing homes typically have very little time left on this earth, and they may prefer seeing their families in person and unmasked to being alone but safe. Ultimately this risk-reward tradeoff should be made at the nursing home and individual level in my mind and should entirely be outside the realm of government, or maybe at most the government could spend money on making sure at risk people have assistance if they want it. I'm a more libertarian leaning chap myself and don't care much for big government spending, but I get that opinions differ here and I'd massively prefer a targeted approach towards people who really need help to the mad lockdown and government spending orgy that's happened here in the USA.

I think the whole thing is utterly baffling. Up until 2020, nobody considered lockdowns as a plausible strategy against disease. At the start, people just wanted to flatten the curve because they all recognized you couldn't eradicate it, and yet for some reason people now seem to think we can either eradicate it or wait until a vaccine magically appears. People somehow have convinced themselves this vaccine will be 100% effective, will be here soon, and is guaranteed to be possible despite no coronavirus vaccine ever having been successfully created. They have no answer for "what happens if we can't make a vaccine?". Worse, people now claim we always intended to lock down forever. But that's not the only revisionism we've experienced.

The masks seem to have become popular after the BLM protests. My opinion is that initially the media railed against anyone protesting lockdown; I've seen things as extreme as wishing death upon people for having these views differing from the media orthodoxy on the virus. However, it was politically forbidden to be too harsh on the BLM protests. Regardless of how you feel about that movement, you can't deny that the media treated the two very differently. Normally I would hope nearly everyone supports the right to protest regardless of whether you agree in the cause, but in this case one was considered okay, even virtuous, while the other abhorrent. The justification that I saw seemed to be that the BLM protesters were more likely to wear masks, and after that the mask thing caught steam. To me, it feels like a psychological trick to make people feel like they're "doing something". It's virtue signalling at its finest. People get so emotional about their obsessive desire to mask people; it's like they want to feel in control, and they want their "team" to be identifiable by a uniform. What's more is that people now act like masks always made sense, and all the things that were initially said about them not being shown to work are now irrelevant. Again, revisionism; we were always at war with Eastasia, covid-1984, etc.

This turned into a bit of a rant, but the tl;dr and crux of my argument is that I don't recognize a point in slowing the spread. I think we've lost the common sense understanding that the curve has to happen and herd immunity has to achieved and have instead dived into totalitarian madness. All of the anti-'rona measures seem to be aimed at slowing the spread, and they just don't make sense to me unless you really buy into the magic vaccine will save us thing. And then on top of that you'd have to prove to me that the masks actually do enough to be effective at stopping the spread, and then you'd have to prove to me that the virus is deadly enough that we should give up our liberties for it.

post.title: To those who believe wearing a mask is taking away your freedom, why?

body: There is a MASSIVE difference between a global pandemic & "there's a mythical brown person in some desert that wants to hurt you, your parents, your children, your god-children, & all your ancestors previous & future, while I stuff my chronies pockets with billions of dollars & you write off all your rights as a citizen".
